ANSWER: Iodine-131 is primarily used in both diagnostic and therapeutic nuclear medicine applications due to its radioisotope properties. In diagnostics, it can be incorporated into radioactive tracers such as iodine-labeled thyroid hormones to assess the function of the thyroid gland. For instance, I-131 uptake studies are commonly used to evaluate for hyperthyroidism or detect thyroid cancer metastases. Therapeutically, I-131 is used in the treatment of hyperthyroidism and thyroid cancer. It is highly effective because the body concentrates iodine in the thyroid, which allows I-131's radiation to target and destroy overactive thyroid cells in cases of hyperthyroidism or cancerous cells in thyroid cancer patients. Its half-life of about 8 days also makes it suitable for long-term treatment options without causing significant radiation exposure to other parts of the body.
